body: have added the benchmark test in a module.
Thanks for a quick response! Yes, that's the best thing to do here - just add a note into doc.

Btw I may also add here that "wikipedia" example is up and running on my home PC for last 5 days with no issues, so at least a basic functionality is fine on FreeBSD 10.1 + OpenJDK 8.

exceptions in a RT node logs, but it's a connection issue not related to the software part. I'll do much more extensive tests with a high-load in the future on this configuration.
Is this PC connected via wireless or direct ethernet cable?
Direct ethernet through a router + cable modem
The changes are depending on https://github.com/druid-io/druid-api/pull/43
@xvrl @drcrallen closing this PR , it was just to show the issue.

@cheddar / @xvrl : I removed the metadata updating in the job and left it as ONLY an indexing task.

I also fixed the last known bug (https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/1363) that I have encountered in local tests.
@gianm Done! Sorry for the long wait, I have been quite busy in the last week or so at work :(
can you also fix the merge conflicts ?

@nishantmonu51 wow, didn't realized this piece of code had change in this way. I have changed my patch to accommodate the new code structure with the fully qualified class name (which I have take straight from a valid EMR cluster I currently have live).
I actually started looking into this code path for other tasks, and I would like to propose using outputFs.getScheme() to determine the type of FS
Ideally then omitting any sort of scheme in the URI will simply use whatever method Hadoop uses to resolve URIs, and we can simply use the appropriate known schemes until Druid has more URI support.
@anubhgup This is not a bug and was intended by design. This change also breaks router logic.
Okay my mistake for closing this. Several of the comments were addressed but I still we need a better description of the changes.
Hi @fjy I think it is Ok to close it now, because as I talked with Eric, he also said that this change should get reviewed by him first. I can get a review on greyhawk repo first.
We are gonna do an internal review of the changes first and then re-make this PR.  So, ok to keep closed.
Added unit test.

What are the intended semantics of loadByPeriod? In my use case, this is breaking things since it leads to a segment getting dropped even though it contains data in my retention period. How can I work around this problem? Currently, I have a retention rule that says "loadByPeriod=7D, dropForever". When I enabled segment merging, any segment that spans that 7D boundary gets dropped by the coordinator.
Thanks @fjy. I can introduce the new rule type. Would it be useful to merge the new rule CL to the main branch, or should I just implement that for local use?
Travis CI failing on SegmentMetadataQueryTest
duh, .. should've run the build

maybe it is not ideal to return size=0 when its unknown as we end up reporting incorrect total size then.
instead, implement ComplexMetricsSerde.inputSizeFn() correctly for various complex aggregators?
@anubhgup feel free to submit a PR, I don't see a reason not to include it in the main branch.

can we make size a `Long` then so that when it returns it will be blank upon `null`? Having a 0 size is misleading.
@cheddar : this is your original code, is it required to be `long` instead of `Long` for size?
nvmnd, I answered my own question. `io.druid.query.metadata.metadata.ColumnAnalysis#fold` would need changed also
and `io.druid.query.metadata.SegmentMetadataQueryRunnerFactory#createRunner`
@drcrallen  I believe you're agreeing towards not giving size information if its not available, with the understanding that totalSize reported will be smaller than actual.
It is worth noting that the realtime tasks build their own RealtimeMetricsMonitor independent of the global MetricsModule.
@himanshug Yes. And we should update the docs as such.
With the improved compression we have, I'm not even sure if this size functionality reports what its supposed to.
Ok, http://druid.io/docs/latest/SegmentMetadataQuery.html indicates `Estimated byte size for the segment columns in TSV format` Rather than "on disk size" so I think we're ok.

@drcrallen @himanshug If we think of the size value as a metric, then I think it's ok to default it to zero.
Druid metrics will default to zero if there is no data for a given row, so it would be consistent with what we do for regular Druid data.
With @xvrl 's argument regarding matching metric behavior I agree this is a reasonable solution.
@xvrl @drcrallen ok, it seems defaulting size to 0 is ok, let me update the docs then.
@drcrallen should we update the rulemanager with the same fix as well?
@xvrl ready to merge.
@xvrl do you know how coveralls coverage can decrease from adding a unit test?
This generally LGTM, assuming it still works :).  Is there a way to add tests?

Can we call it `loadByOverlapPeriod` instead?

Also, those semantics about dropping even though it has relevant data are very unintuitive, was that introduced when we added the router?  Just as a general rule, the load/drop/retention rule's semantics should be defined according to what makes sense for the retention of segments.  If the router's logic cannot re-use them as is, then it shouldn't be a problem with the interface, it just means that the router cannot reuse that same logic...

@cheddar Coveralls does funky things sometimes. It appears to compare to the latest number it has, which can be a different branch if master failed. Numbers across JDK versions are also different, and sometimes it seems to compare only one of the numbers with the average. In this case, the link shows that it never got the numbers for the JDK 7 build, so it only used the JDK 8 numbers.

@cheddar : @xvrl  and I briefly spoke about what the best way to test this kind of stuff is. Due to the overhead of setting up and tearing down a yarn and hdfs temporary single-node-cluster, a test outside the default `maven test` route would be preferable

It is worth noting that I used this technique for the recompressing segments and reduced our metrics datasize by about 20%. So _in general_ the technique works. The question simply remains how best to test that this task still functions.

A few options for adding in hadoopy tests are:
1. Add hadoopy stuff in the official integration test
2. Add self-contained but still integration tests as a separate maven profile (example `maven clean test -P IT`)
3. Manually set `@Ignore` until we decide it is time to run the test

Great PR!

Looking at the code, it looks like Guava's function composition signature is that it takes the outer function first, but we are calling it with the Having clause in the outer function, so it is exactly as you expect @mrijke 

Can you try inverting the arguments at

https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/processing/src/main/java/io/druid/query/groupby/GroupByQuery.java#L106-L126

And see if that fixes the test?
@himanshug Yes, that fixed it! I've updated the commit accordingly. Thanks a lot!

I was able to reproduce; after stopping zookeeper my thread logs:
`WARN [CuratorFramework-0-SendThread(192.168.33.243:2181)] org.apache.zookeeper.ClientCnxn - Session 0x0 for server null, unexpected error, closing socket connection and attempting reconnect
java.net.ConnectException: Connection refused

After sending a SIGTERM the process remain running, although I did not receive further messages in logging.

I've uploaded a `jstack-l <pid>` threaddump to:
http://paste.ubuntu.com/11259668/

Hi @flowbehappy Thanks for the patch! Would you mind describing the issue and solution (high level is fine) in the description of your PR?

Specifically, if you have any particular error keywords please include them in the description so that people searching for a fix later can find this PR.

:+1: 

As a general comment: If you have any good ways to test failure or error cases that would be awesome. (Does not need to block this PR though)

It works locally on a yarn single-node cluster:

this is causing ITTwitterQueryTest in integration-tests to fail with ClassCastException while fetching bySegmentResults on historical nodes with ClassCastException.

java.lang.ClassCastException: io.druid.query.Result cannot be cast to io.druid.query.metadata.metadata.SegmentAnalysis
        at io.druid.query.metadata.SegmentMetadataQueryQueryToolChest$4.compare(SegmentMetadataQueryQueryToolChest.java:222) ~[druid-processing-0.7.3-SNAPSHOT.jar:0.7.3-SNAPSHOT]

can you have a look  at the changes again ?

@nishantmonu51 this code was added before 0.7.1.1, did we run integration tests back then and they passed or did we not run the tests at that time or is this a nwe test? just trying to understand what changed.
probably dint ran integration tests then, reverting the changes in this PR makes the test pass.
I am checking

@himanshug / @cheddar / @xvrl 
As per Eric's request I have squashed the pre and post merge requirements. This required a bunch of manipulating the codepaths in the query toolchests, and some changing of the codepath entry points in the unit tests.
caught up into something else, will look at it in 1-2 hrs. let me know if it is blocking u guys or something

this failure was undetected from a long time, 
can we also add a UT that catches it ?
Hi @drcrallen description added.

Hi @himanshug , this PR is not intend to introduce the feature you mention, but fix it.
And I also tried adding those hadoop config files to classpath like this:
`java -classpath /usr/loca/hadoop/etc/hadoop:other-classpath:...`
or 
`java -classpath /usr/loca/hadoop/etc/hadoop/*:other-classpath:...`
But it just didn't work. Node that hadoop is install in /usr/loca/hadoop. 
I'm using Hadoop 2.5.1.

All I can say is that https://github.com/zenops/cookbooks/blob/master/cookbooks/druid/templates/default/runner.sh#L27-L29 is working fine for a very long time in production, i.e. I too think this is a configuration issue rather than a druid bug.

@sixtus that's weird it doesn't work for me :( 
Besides even if it works, I still think this bug is worthy to fix for someone who chose to set hadoop config in that way.

@himanshug, this is actually about loading in jvm system properties that start with "hadoop." as Hadoop configuration keys, rather than druid runtime.properties. It is true that the keys could just be put in the hadoop XMLs (or in the "jobProperties" of the hadoop spec/task) but since we already support this in the druid-hdfs-storage module and in the hadoop indexer, I think for consistency sake it makes sense to do it everywhere.

So, this patch looks good to me.

I actually think it makes sense that they exit with those codes, since it lets you know what signal was used to kill them. That's a pretty standard thing that Unix processes do. Can you please explain a bit what your setup looks like and why an exit status of 0 would help you out?

Would wrapping the calls in something like SQLMetadataStorageActionHandler.retryingHandle work? (It would have to be made into a static I suppose)

Fwiw, I just noticed that Postgres doesn't have a reasonable implementation of isTransientException, and filed #1382 for that.

Hmm, it looks like the only interesting non-daemon thread left is Thread-43, which is trying to unannounce the service from ZK and is in the middle of a retry loop. I _think_ it should exit after about 20 minutes when all of its retries are exhausted. Do you know if it was stuck for longer than that?

The reason I think it's about 20 minutes is that Curator's retry policy is `new BoundedExponentialBackoffRetry(1000, 45000, 30)`.

Would it make sense to have a shorter retry policy? We do want to at least try somewhat hard to cleanly shut things down when we get a SIGTERM, and if ZK is unavailable I think it does make sense to wait a bit. Maybe not 20 minutes.

A non-zero exit status signifies an abnormal program termination. See references.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exit_status
https://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_node/Exit-Status.html
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/System.html#exit(int)

An exit status of 0, which signifies success, will help my start/stop/monitoring scripts determine if the process was shutdown successfully as a result of an administrative action, or if it failed during its execution and should be respawned or trigger alerts etc.
I didn't time the processes afterwards, but when i came back after lunch they were gone :) so it is probably as you say then, that they wait for the 20 min timeout.

@gianm it is fine to do it for consistency, but my concern was that it should have worked even without this PR. We put all our common hadoop configurations in the said files and it has been working fine.

@himanshug I agree with both you and Gian. This change is good for consistency and people expecting to use `hadoop.` properties, but we may have underlying classpath issues somewhere.

@flowbehappy would you mind help tracking down why you are not able to use the hadoop config parameters?
@himanshug Happy to merge once you squash commits. Tests would be nice indeed

Sure, I'm going to add the UT pretty soon.

However, I wanted to keep the commit history as it has the story of what happened. If I squash them then the information of how really eagerness is applied is lost. currently, one could go to the specific commit (https://github.com/himanshug/druid/commit/5473f7aa4fbc2a1a35d1e588fd912a59c79f065e) to see what really changed overall. Please let me know if that does not sound reasonable to you.
@himanshug seems reasonable, go for it
@drcrallen I would go even further and just scrap all the static methods in favor of public static constants called `IDENTITY`, `FINALIZING`, `DESERIALIZING`.
@himanshug sounds reasonable. In that case let's update the second commit message to indicates what this fixes, so it doesn't look like we undo and redo the same thing.

We probably do have hadoop classpath problems. Ideally you wouldn't ever need to set hadoopy stuff on the overlord classpath, but instead could define all you need within the task itself, but I (and I think other devs) define the hadoop configs in part of the overlord classpath (local runner) to keep things chugging smoothly.

@drcrallen We still need to have hadoop configs on the classpath to pick up all the necessary settings to know how to talk to the hadoop cluster and hdfs. I think it's also useful to have good defaults in those configs so applications submitting tasks don't have to worry about those things.
Thanks @gbuisson! I can't find your CLA on file, do you mind quickly filling out the online form here druid.io/community/cla.html ?
Can you add appropriate unit tests for this?

I'd rather have them be getters so we can change the underlying mechanism later if needed.

For example guava Functions uses a bunch of enums, which I don't think we need to do yet, but it would be nice to have the ability to do that without ever changing code.
Is this a performance thing?
Silly coveralls
@cheddar : no its a general code cleanliness thing. I had made a change as part of the query path rewrite but wanted it to be its own PR instead of hanging up with the query path stuff

Given that it is just moving statically built anonymous classes behind a static interface to static objects, I'm not sure what's more clean about it.  But, I also have no objections to it...

that said, coveralls is clearly indicating that we have no tests for these things, this would be a great time to just add some simple unit tests that make sure the static methods return functions that do the right thing :)
The high-level direction seems good.  The biggest question in my mind is do we keep the Writable InputRow or do we adjust the jobs to pull out the key/value and all that now?

Hrm, I fear that I was not clear in my original comments.  I was originally attempting to just advocate for not adding more things to the pre/post methods and instead do it all in the `mergeResults()` method.  Where, at some point in the future, we could discuss the right API for the toolchests and convert things to that.  That is, I just didn't want to add to the technical debt...

It looks like we now have a new API defined as part of these refactorings, so this is gonna require more time to think about that API and make sure that nobody in the community has implemented their own query type (I don't think anyone has)...  This should also bump the version up to 0.9 if we have done a 0.8 release before this gets merged...
@xvrl @nishantmonu51  added the UT
@himanshug great, once build passes I'll merge, and then we can cherry-pick into 0.7.x branch to hopefully release 0.7.3 as stable :)
Added more tests. Hopefully Coveralls is kind today.
Thank you, i Filled the form.
Merci!
